docs.lead_paragraph: A robust economy and years of Government pressure have helped move minority groups closer to the mainstream. But when it comes to health, studies show a stubborn, daunting and in some respects growing disparity between black and white Americans. For decades, blacks have suffered higher death rates from nearly all major causes. Although life expectancy has increased for all groups, differences persist. And Government and academic research shows a widening gap between blacks and others in the incidences of asthma, diabetes, major infectious diseases and several forms of cancer.

headline.main: Health Gap Grows, With Black Americans Trailing Whites, Studies Say

docs.abstract: Studies show, that despite robust economy and years of Government pressure that has helped move minority groups closer to mainstream, there remains stubborn, daunting and in some respects growing disparity in health care between black and white Americans; charts (M)
docs.snippet: A robust economy and years of Government pressure have helped move minority groups closer to the mainstream. But when it comes to health, studies show a stubborn, daunting and in some respects growing disparity between black and white Americans.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: IN October, Dr. Anthony Tonzola received payment from the United Healthcare health maintenance organization in the amount of nine cents. He knew better than to cash it. It's much better saved as a tangible proof of the decline of doctors under managed care. In the last five years, Dr. Tonzola, a general surgeon, has seen the payment for mastectomies drop from $2,500 to $900. His personal income has gone down by two-thirds. But even beyond the financial consequences, he has seen his authority as a physician undercut by having to get on the phone every time he wants to make a medical judgment. ''We no longer make decisions,'' he says. ''The mood in the doctor's lounge is one of frustration, depression and anger.''
docs.abstract: Dr Anthony Tonzola, chief of surgery at Rahway Hospital, discusses the union for physicians he has started in New Jersey and his plans to begin collective bargaining with health insurance networks; believes that only organizing can give doctors the leverage to fight health maintenance organizations that are reducing their income and prestige but also their freedom to act on their medical judgment; so far he has enlisted 700 doctors, out of some 16,000 medical doctors in the state; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Yasmin Ramos delivers the knock on the door that no one wants to answer. She is a senior public health adviser for New York City, a petite woman six months' pregnant whose job includes untangling the web of sexual partners that begins with a single case of H.I.V. Once, as she searched for a woman exposed to H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, Ms. Ramos unwittingly stumbled into a brothel. When she visits certain public housing projects, she raps on the door and jumps to the side, wary of gunshots. Often, she needs only to pick up the phone and call people from the clinic where she works in Jamaica, Queens.

headline.main: Breaking the H.I.V. Chain; Counselors Battle Spread of Infection -- and Despair

docs.abstract: New York City's Bureau of Sexually Transmitted Disease Control counsels people who test positive for HIV and seeks to notify their sex partners, process known as contact tracing or partner notification; contract tracing is common public health strategy for fighting sexually transmitted disease, but it is contentious practice when applied to HIV, because of stigma attached to the virus; supporters say tracing offers the best way to protect rights of people unknowingly exposed to the disease; Una Byfield, Jeffrey King, Yasmin Ramos and Yvan Pompilus, counselors at clinic in Jamaica, Queens, comment; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: FRANK PANZARELLA is the director of the Connecticut Council on Occupational Safety and Health, a nonprofit, statewide organization based in Hartford. Its members includes local unions, labor councils, health and safety activists and health professionals and its goals are to to solve workplace health and safety problems, support new legislation and better enforcement of existing laws as well as provide training to workers and employers. ConnectiCOSH, as the organization is known, is one of about 25 ''COSH'' groups around the country: relatively small non-governmental organizations dependent to some extent on Federal financing from, among others, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health.

headline.main: Q&A/Frank Panzarella; Workplace Safety, at the State Level

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Nov. 17 terrorist attack at Luxor, Egypt, in which 58 foreign tourists were killed, has had a wide impact on travel, but has not halted all trips to Egypt. The State Department quickly issued two Public Announcements, but no Travel Warning, which is issued only in situations where the Government believes it cannot protect its citizens. A number of major tour companies canceled scheduled trips; others postponed departures. Some are still operating cruises and tours into the Luxor area. Although the Muslim fundamentalist group linked to the terrorism issued a statement on Dec. 8 saying that it was forswearing attacks on tourists as a means to its political goals, many Americans still do not want to go to Egypt. Valerie Wilson, president of a New York travel agency bearing her name, said she had clients in the area on Nov. 17, and that people with reservations soon after that were generally ready to continue. ''But now we aren't getting any new requests,'' she said, ''even through security has increased tremendously and it's probably safer than usual.''

docs.lead_paragraph: On the day he was to have what he would later call his ''meeting with the devil,'' Randy Warren woke up early. It was the last day of April 1997, and Warren had spent a restless night in a hotel at the Toronto airport, two hours from his home, awaiting the morning arrival of two strangers, businessmen from New Jersey. The strangers were executives of the Celgene Corporation, a tiny pharmaceutical company that is seeking Government approval to market thalidomide, the world's most notorious agent of birth defects. Warren, the founder and chief executive officer of the Thalidomide Victims Association of Canada, had come to provide these men with living proof of their product's ruinous past.

docs.lead_paragraph: There's no longer any political news, a reporter friend confided recently, explaining why ''human interest'' stories were oozing like syrup across his newspaper's front pages. We're in the Bland Decade now, a time when citizens march on Washington not to affect politics but to vow they'll be better people and when politicians speak out mainly to urge niceness: volunteer your time, enter into dialogues on race, hire someone off welfare, please. Apparently we need little more than charity, moral uplift and perhaps a modest program or two. Politics is dead, or so it seems. The easiest explanation for this torpor is that the nation is fat, like an overstuffed bear starting hibernation. It's no longer the economy, stupid. Six years ago, a prolonged recession hurt white-collar workers, giving some urgency to the politics of ''change.'' Prosperity, though, is a powerful sedative. Forget politics for now, we seem to be saying. Let's compare stock portfolios, banter about culture and identity and tut-tut over problems decades hence, like an insolvent Social Security trust fund or excessive greenhouse gases.

headline.main: Whatever Happened to Politics?; When Naptime Is Over

docs.abstract: Robert B Reich article on political torpor in nation, likened to 'overstuffed bear starting hibernation'; says that, at first glance, great economic contests have been won: wealth is exploding, unemployment is low, inflation is quiescent, consumer confidence is high; perceives, on the other hand, underlying problems among Americans who are not so rich; predicts that when nap time is over, political debate will revive because boom has bypassed too many, and gap between winners and losers has grown too wide; drawings (M)
docs.snippet: There's no longer any political news, a reporter friend confided recently, explaining why ''human interest'' stories were oozing like syrup across his newspaper's front pages. We're in the Bland Decade now, a time when citizens march on Washington...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration unveiled proposals today to help workers save for retirement, part of an effort by the White House to keep some momentum behind a series of policy initiatives it has set out in recent weeks. Administration officials said the proposals stemmed from Mr. Clinton's desire to improve the financial security of workers, especially members of the baby-boom generation, as they head toward retirement. The proposals, in the works for months, will be highlighted by the President during the State of the Union address on Tuesday. They include provisions to make it easier to contribute to Individual Retirement Accounts through payroll deductions and to create tax breaks for small businesses that set up pension plans.

headline.main: Clinton Proposal Would Help Workers Save for Retirement
